description:
doc: Remove obsolete references to weekly releases.

This was misleading and often confusing for new users.

Leaving the actual weekly release history page for historical reference.

messages.text:
Hello golang-dev@googlegroups.com,

I'd like you to review this change to
https://go.googlecode.com/hg/

http://codereview.appspot.com/6555053/diff/4001/doc/devel/release.html File doc/devel/release.html (right): http://codereview.appspot.com/6555053/diff/4001/doc/devel/release.html#newcode6 doc/devel/release.html:6: and the Mercurial change log s/^and t/T http://codereview.appspot.com/6555053/diff/4001/doc/devel/release.html#newcode7 doc/devel/release.html:7: has full details.

s/has /&the/ http://codereview.appspot.com/6555053/diff/4001/doc/devel/release.html#newcode31 doc/devel/release.html:31: The go1.0.0 release corresponds to revert this change

*** Submitted as http://code.google.com/p/go/source/detail?r=bb0633b9007b ***

doc: Remove obsolete references to weekly releases.

This was misleading and often confusing for new users.

Leaving the actual weekly release history page for historical reference.

R=golang-dev, rsc, adg
CC=golang-dev
http://codereview.appspot.com/6555053

Committer: Andrew Gerrand <adg@golang.org>
there is no such thing as go1.0.0. there is only go1.

Then I think that is confusing, because go1 refers to both the
original "go1 release" and the "go1 specification" as defined in:
http://golang.org/doc/go1compat.html and which applies also to
subsequent bugfix releases.

I would be fine with deleting that whole sentence too.

On Sun, Sep 23, 2012 at 8:16 PM, Russ Cox <rsc@golang.org> wrote:
> there is no such thing as go1.0.0. there is only go1.

Hello golang-dev@googlegroups.com, rsc@golang.org, adg@golang.org (cc: golang-dev@googlegroups.com),

Please take another look.

subject: code review 6555053: doc: Remove obsolete references to weekly releases.
